QuestionStem: A student drank a bottle of water during a car ride up a mountain. At the top of the mountain, the student capped the plastic bottle. During the drive back down the mountain, what might happen to the bottle?

options.AnswerText: A. It will expand because the air pressure is lower at the bottom of the mountain.
options.Feedback: Recall how the force of gravity and air pressure change with elevation.

options.AnswerText: B. It will contract because the air pressure is higher at the bottom of the mountain.
C. It will become lighter. The air particles in the bottle weigh less because they are from the top of the mountain.
options.Feedback: Recall how the force of gravity and air pressure change with elevation.

options.AnswerText: D. It will not change because it is empty and contains no air.
options.Feedback: Recall how the force of gravity and air pressure change with elevation.

FinalIncorrectFeedback: Air pressure decreases as elevation increases. When the bottle was capped at the higher elevation, a low number of air particles was trapped inside the bottle. As the car drove to a lower elevation, the air pressure outside of the bottle increased and pushed inward on the bottle, causing it to collapse inward.
